title: Non-Constitutional Courts and Constitutional Change: Lessons from Germany

affiliation.name: Adjunct Assistant Professor of Political Science, DePaul University (Chicago) and Visiting Scholar, Institute for Advanced Legal Studies (London). I am grateful to John Gardner, Dieter Grimm, Thomas Henne, Oliver Lepsius, Janet Smith, an anonymous reviewer, and members of the Max-Planck Institute for European Legal History for helpful advice and encouragement.

cf. A. Sweet, “Constitutional Dialogues: The Protection of Human Rights in France, Germany, Italy, and Spain” in S. Kenney, J. Reitz, and W. Reisinger (eds.), Constitutional Dialogues in Cross-National Perspective (1999), 46.

On the controversy surrounding the RG, see generally G. Lübbe-Wolff, “Safeguards of Civil and Constitutional Rights—The Debate on the Role of the Reichsgericht” in H. Wellenreuter (ed.), German and American Constitutional Thought (1990).

reference.unstructured: In addition to works cited, the following historical sketch draws freely from these sources: Brünneck, n. 10 above; D. Grimm, Recht und Staat der bürgerlichen Gesellschaft (1987), 264–277; J. Ipsen, Richterrecht und Verfassung (1975), 104–115; H. Kröner, Die Eigentumsgarantie in der Rechtssprechung des Bundesgerichtshofs (1961); H. Maurer, Allgemeines Verwaltungsrecht (8th edn. 1992), 12–21 and 609–673; and R. Wendt, Eigentum und Gesetzgebung (1985), 17–64.

For the legal implications of these decisions, see C. Schmitt, “Die Auflösung des Enteignungsbegriffs,” in Schmitt, n. 33 above. On the property rights decisions generally, see P. Caldwell, Popular Sovereignty and the Crisis of German Constitutional Law: The Theory and Practice of Weimar Constitutionalism (1997), 148–160.
See “Gesetzes zur Ordnung des Wasserhaushalts von 16 Oktober 1976” in I BGBl 3017.
BVGE 58, 137. See also Maurer, n. 37 above.

Nigel G. Foster, German Legal System and Laws (2nd edn. 1993), 43.
On the BGH's extensive jurisdiction, see ibid., 238.
Cf T. Ingman, n. 23 above, 16–23 and S. Wasby, The Supreme Court in the Federal Judicial System (2nd edn. 1984), 56–58.
“Gesetz über das Bundesverfassungsgericht” in I BGBl 243.

Mass-to-Light Ratio of Intermediate and Old Clusters in the Magellanic Clouds
Experimental Constitutionalism: A Comparative Analysis of The Institutional Bases of Rights Enforcement in Post-Communist Hungary

items.abstract: <jats:p>The observed central velocity dispersion of a stellar system is dependent on the mass distribution and the velocity distribution function. For the past several years a program has been undertaken to determine central velocity dispersions of LMC and SMC clusters for comparison with galactic clusters. The mass-to-light ratio (M/L) estimates so obtained should be considerably more accurate than those obtained by tidal arguments (Chun 1978, Elson &amp; Freeman 1985).</jats:p><jats:p>Accurate radial velocities (mean error = 1.3 km s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) have been obtained for a sample of K-type giants with the CTIO 4m telescope and échelle spectrograph with CCD detector. All of the stars observed were within two core radii of the cluster centre. Multiple observations at several epochs (1984 and 1989) were used to determine the velocity errors.</jats:p><jats:p>The central M/L in solar units has been estimated from single component isotropic King models (King 1966), with the assumption that the distribution of mass follows that of the light. Observed values for the total integrated light and core radius were taken from the literature (in particular, from Chun 1978, van den Bergh 1981, Mateo 1987).</jats:p>
title: Mass-to-light ratio of intermediate and old clusters in the Magellanic Clouds
